quoteFirst: Rex had, by this time, undergone his riding-lessons, and his appearance was fairly certain, since Mr. Weston used to dismiss him at
quoteLast: , telling him to hurry up and get ready for school. But Billy was a will-oâ€™-the-wisp creature, and rules and regulations meant little to him.
title: The Twins of Emu Plains
author: Bruce, Mary Grant, 1878-1958; Mills, J. Dewar [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: At nine precisely he was in his carriage with his coachman on the box to drive his horses, his man Mole also, and Piggy the little dog in with him. He knows it was nine, because he asked the butler what time it was as he left the dining-room, and the butler answered "
quoteLast: , my Lord"; moreover, the clock in the dining-room, the one on the stairs and his own watch, all corroborated the butler's statement.
title: On Nothing & Kindred Subjects
author: Belloc, Hilaire, 1870-1953

quoteLast: on the first day of the year seven vast crowds stood before the seven principal entrances to Hugo's; seven crowds of immortal souls enclosed in the bodies of women. They meant to begin the year well by an honest attempt to get something for nothing.
title: Hugo: A Fantasia on Modern Themes
author: Bennett, Arnold, 1867-1931

title:
The Mountain that was 'God'
Being a Little Book About the Great Peak Which the Indians Named 'Tacoma' but Which is Officially Called 'Rainier'
author: Williams, John H. (John Harvey), 1864-

quoteFirst: Not a shutter was down! not a bus was about! There were three men in sight, one of whom was a policeman; a market-cart full of cabbages, and a dilapidated looking cab. George pulled out his watch and looked at it: it was
quoteLast: ! He stood still and counted his pulse. He stooped down and felt his legs. Then, with his watch still in his hand, he went up to the policeman, and asked him if he knew what the time was.
title: Three men in a boat (to say nothing of the dog)
author: Jerome, Jerome K. (Jerome Klapka), 1859-1927

quoteLast: they heard steps in the hall. They passed down the stairs. Boys from the rooms along the hallway were going to the lecture. Stan got up and disconnected the microphone.
title: A Yankee Flier Over Berlin
author: Montgomery, Rutherford G. (Rutherford George), 1896-1985; Laune, Paul, 1899-1977 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: It was only when she reached the pavement above the pit again that she realized that the worst possible calamity had taken place. Not one member of the office staff but three saw her climb out of the excavation, for it was now
quoteLast: and a rush to reach the office on time was in progress.
title: The horror expert
author: Long, Frank Belknap, 1903-1994; Schulz, Robert, 1928-1978 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: We are going to try and pick up the cable of 1865 in two thousand five hundred fathoms (and we mean to succeed too); therefore should the cable we are now paying out part, it can be understood how easy it would be to raise it from a depth of three hundred fathoms. At
quoteLast: we signalled to the Terrible to sound, and received a reply, one hundred and sixty fathoms. At half-past eleven we informed her that when at the buoy off Heart's Content she should have her paddle-box boat and two cutters ready to be alongside immediately, for holding the bight of the cable during the splice and laying the shore end.
title: The Story of the Atlantic Telegraph
author: Field, Henry M. (Henry Martyn), 1822-1907
